thread.title: For Pennridge's Urichs, a battle bigger than football
thread.title_full: For Pennridge's Urichs, a battle bigger than football

title: For Pennridge's Urichs, a battle bigger than football
text:
More coverage: Southeastern Pa. high school sports 
"With my mom's health, you have to try to stay positive, pray every night, and hope she gets better," said Dean Urich, a senior defensive back for the Rams. 
Kathy Urich, who often uses a wheelchair or walker to get around, was diagnosed 3 1/2 years ago. 
"I had been telling my doctors for 18 months that there was something wrong with my left breast," she said. "It was not the lump that most women get, but a thickening of the breast tissue." 
Opting against surgery or traditional chemotherapy, Urich first tried hormone therapy. "It worked for about a year," she said. "Then I was put on oral chemotherapy. I stopped that in July when a PET scan showed the chemotherapy drug was not working and the cancer was progressing." 
Urich now sees an oncologist at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York. She orally takes a scorpion venom extract that is supposed to target and kill cancer cells. It costs about $700 per bottle. 
"I'm trying to fight this through non-traditional means," said Urich, whose youngest son Cole, 14, is a defensive back for Pennridge's freshman squad. "I think it's my only option at this point." 
Urich, who became a grandmother in April, is also aided by her husband Butch, eldest son Jake, 22, and Jake's girlfriend, Shannon. Her sister, Terry, retired from her full-time job and moved with her two daughters to the Urich's home to be Kathy's full-time caretaker. 
Last month, Pennridge's football booster club organized a dodgeball tournament at NexGen High Performance Training Center in Telford that raised about $7,000 to help Urich's fight against cancer. T-shirts are being sold in school and at games. 
"It's been a difficult time, but so many people have been supportive and encouraging," said Dean Urich, who plans to study exercise physiology in college. 
Kathy and Dean Urich were honorary captains for a nonleague contest vs. Central Bucks West on Sept. 18. Dean made a third-quarter interception to help clinch a 34-0 triumph at Helman Field. 
"Dean has always been kind of an underdog," said Kathy Urich, who was wheeled out to midfield by Dean for the coin toss. "It was amazing to watch him make that play. It was like the stars aligned." 
For those wanting to donate, checks can be made payable to "The Benefit of Kathy Urich" and mailed to Urich's home at 108 Ridge Run Road, Sellersville, Pa. 18960. The Breakdown 
No. 19 Pennridge at No. 14 Neshaminy, 6 p.m. Saturday. 
History: 
Neshaminy holds a 13-7 lead in the series, which began in 1956. 
Last season: Pennridge christened Helman Field, its new home, with a 21-14 victory. 
Key Matchup I: Redskins receivers Denzel Hughes and Zach Tredway vs. Rams cornerbacks Ryan Cuthbert and Joe Piacine. 
Key Matchup II: Pennridge center Luke Basquill (5-11, 205) vs. Neshaminy defensive tackles Eddie Parry (6-0, 285) and Kyle Osterhoudt (6-2, 245). 
Pick: Neshaminy, 31-21. 
1,239: Combined passing and rushing yards for C.R. North's Brandon McIlwain. 
623: Rushing yards on 84 attempts for Pottsgrove's Tyrell Barr. 
38: Years since Marple Newtown (4-0) went 5-0 to start a season. 
35: Tackles, including 15 solos, for C.B. East middle linebacker Jack Lamb.
